title: Equalize It
problem_statement:
Equalize It

Problem Description

Given the following:

  • A non-negative even integer N.
  • An array Arr of N non-negative long integers.

You can apply the below operation any number of times:

  • Choose a number from the array and increase or decrease it by 1.
  • The number should be non-negative after applying the operation.

Calculate the minimum number of operations you need to perform such that exactly N/2 numbers of the array are the numbers that are squares of a number and exactly N/2 numbers of the array are the numbers that are not a square of a number.

Note: 0-based indexing is followed.

Function description

Complete the function equalizeIt provided in the editor. This function takes the following 2 parameters and returns the required answer:

  • N: Represents the length of the array Arr
  • Arr: Represents the array

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
6
2 5 6 7 8 9
Output:
2

Explanation: Given N = 6 and Arr = [2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. We need N/2 = 3 squares and 3 non-squares.

You will apply 2 operations on the Arr:

  • Decrease Arr[1] by 1 (5 becomes 4).
  • Increase Arr[4] by 1 (8 becomes 9).

Now the array Arr becomes [2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 9].

  • 4, 9, 9 are squares of 2, 3 and 3 respectively. (3 squares)
  • 2, 6, 7 are not squares of a number. (3 non-squares)

This satisfies the condition with 2 operations.

Example 2:

Input:
4
0 0 0 0
Output:
4

Explanation: Given N = 4 and Arr = [0, 0, 0, 0]. We need N/2 = 2 squares and 2 non-squares.

You will apply 4 operations on the Arr:

  • Increase Arr[0] by 2 (0 becomes 2).
  • Increase Arr[1] by 2 (0 becomes 2).

Now the array Arr becomes [2, 2, 0, 0].

  • 0, 0 are squares of a number. (2 squares)
  • 2, 2 are not squares of a number. (2 non-squares)

This satisfies the condition with 4 operations.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ T ≤ 10
  • 1 ≤ N ≤ 105
  • 0 ≤ Arr[i] ≤ 109

Note: N is always even.
